Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Patient ID: [REDACTED]
Date of procedure: [REDACTED]
Attending physician: Dr. E. Rossi
Assistants: Pulmonary fellow; radiology technologist; bronchoscopy nurse.

Pre-procedure diagnosis: 19 mm part-solid right lower lobe superior segment nodule with adjacent spread-through-airspaces on CT.
Post-procedure diagnosis: Same.
Indication: Local ablation of early lung adenocarcinoma with extended parenchymal margin in a nonsurgical candidate.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 mm endotracheal tube; ASA class III.

Procedures performed:
1. Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy with cone-beam CT guidance.
2. Transbronchial microwave ablation of right lower lobe superior segment nodule using Emprint catheter.
3. Adjunct bronchoscopic thermal vapor ablation to the surrounding segment.

Procedure description: Navigation bronchoscopy was used to reach the superior segment bronchus. A cone-beam CT acquisition confirmed catheter position. An Emprint catheter was positioned appropriately, and a 10-minute microwave ablation was delivered, yielding a well-centered ablation zone with an approximate 5 mm margin. To address suspected microscopic spread beyond the visible nodule, a dedicated vapor catheter was then positioned in the adjacent segmental airway, and thermal vapor energy was delivered to the surrounding lung parenchyma per manufacturer protocol. Post-treatment cone-beam CT demonstrated an extended area of ground-glass change enveloping the primary ablation zone and adjacent spread-through-airspaces. Airways remained patent on bronchoscopy.

Estimated blood loss: <5 mL.
Complications: Transient post-procedural fever expected from vapor ablation; no pneumothorax.
Disposition: Extubated in the operating room and admitted for overnight observation with antipyretic therapy; follow-up CT planned at 3 and 12 months.
